presentation.title: Farms in the 100-year floodplain
presentation.runninghead: Farm damage avoided by flood regulation
presentation.description: Values resulting from flood regulation by ecosystems, including precipitation, ecosystems capable of providing infiltration or detention of flood waters, and farmland at risk of flooding (within the 100-year floodplain). Flow models are used to connect beneficiaries to potential sources of flood water and quantify the action of natural "sinks" that slow, detain, or infiltrate flood water.

page.name: Assessment of farmland at risk from flooding (100-year floodplain)
page.title: Introduction
page.runninghead: Farmland at risk from flooding (100-year floodplain)
page.description: This model considers farmland within the 100-year floodplain as a potential beneficiary of flood regulation. Depending on their magnitude and timing, floods can cause severe crop damage. These models map flows from flood sources (precipitation), sinks (areas whose topography, vegetation, and soils promote detention and infiltration of flood water), and beneficiary groups and link these via a flow model accounting for the downstream movement of floodwater. To map farms at risk of flooding, farmland and floodplain extents data were simply intersected.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Annual precipitation
page.title: Annual precipitation
page.description:
Annual precipitation.

Role in models

Precipitation data are used as the "source" of floodwater. Data are currently at an annual time scale; event-based models may be added as external model integration improves within the ARIES system, allowing flood modeling at finer time scales. These data are passed to the flow model to estimate actual flood mitigation given the location of sources of floodwater and beneficiaries at risk of flooding.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of precipitation per year.

Source

PRISM Climate Group, Oregon State University.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: PRISM
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Successional stage
page.title: Successional stage
page.description:
Forest successional stage is an important influence on evapotranspiration and infiltration in forest ecosystems.

Role in models

Successional stage is used as input into a probabilistic model estimating the contribution of vegetation and soils, or "green infrastructure" in infiltrating floodwater. All else being equal, later successional forests are assumed to provide greater mitigation of floodwater than early successional forests.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

BLM Interagency Vegetation Mapping Project (WA/OR).
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Interagency Vegetation Mapping Project.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Mean days precipitation per year
page.title: Mean days precipitation per year
page.description:
The number of days of precipitation per year across the landscape.

Role in models

Since the flood models currently run on an annual time scale, assessing overall flood regulation capacity rather than being event-based, the mean number of days of precipitation per year is used as a proxy for how often the soils are saturated. If rainfall is relatively uncommon, the landscape may better be able to absorb floodwater than in wetter regions. Mean days of precipitation per month data are also available. To run flood models on an event-by-event basis, data or proxies for variables like soil saturation, precipitation, and snowmelt would be needed, which often have limited availability on a landscape scale.

Representation

Data are categorical, and have been pre-discretized based on the number of days of precipitation per year.

Source

PRISM Climate Group, Oregon State University.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: PRISM
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Hydrologic soils group
page.title: Hydrologic soils group
page.description:
Different soil types have different infiltration capacities. See http://www.ems-i.com/wmshelp/Hydrologic_Models/Calculators/Composite_Runoff_Coefficients/Selecting_the_Method.htm.

Role in models

Soils are classified from group A (highest infiltraiton capacity) to D (lowest infiltration capacity); group accounts for maximum yearly wetness, degree of soil freezing, bare soil surface, and swelling of clays, but does not account for slope. HSG along with slope and impervious surface data were used to estimate the soil infiltration component of flood control in the flood sink models.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

SSURGO soils data.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: USDA-NRCS SSURGO soils database.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Slope
page.title: Slope
page.description:
Slope strongly affects runoff by influencing potential infiltration.

Role in models

Since hydrologic soils group classifications do not account for slope, slope data along with HSG and impervious surface data were used to estimate the soil infiltration component of flood control in the flood sink models. Greater infiltration is expected on level slopes than on steep slopes where runoff occurs quickly.

Representation

Data are in physical units of degrees slope.

Source

Derived from a global 90-m SRTM digital elevation model.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Derived from Shuttle Radar Topography Mission data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Percent impervious cover
page.title: Percent impervious cover
page.description:
The amount of impervious surface (e.g., buildings, pavement) on the landscape.

Role in models

We use impervious surface along with slope and hydrologic soils group to estimate the soil infiltration component of flood control in the flood sink models. Zero infiltration is expected on impervious surfaces.

Representation

Data show the percentage of the land surface with impervious cover.

Source

2001 National Land Cover Dataset.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: National Land Cover Dataset.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation height
page.title: Vegetation height
page.description:
Height of the tree canopy above the ground surface.

Role in models

Vegetation height is used as input into a probabilistic model estimating the contribution of vegetation and soils, or "green infrastructure" in infiltrating floodwater. All else being equal, taller tree canopies are assumed to intercept more precipitation, leading to greater mitigation of floodwater than forests of shorter stature.

Representation

Data are in physical units of meters, showing height of the tree canopy above the ground surface.

Source

Puget Sound LIDAR Consortium.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Puget Sound LIDAR Consortium.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Percent tree canopy cover
page.title: Percent tree canopy cover
page.description:
Percent tree canopy cover influences rooting depths, root densities, and transpiration rates, affecting their ability to aid in infiltration of floodwater.

Role in models

Tree canopy cover is used as input into a probabilistic model estimating the contribution of vegetation and soils, or "green infrastructure" in infiltrating floodwater. All else being equal, greater infiltration and evapotranspiration, leading to greater mitigation of floodwater, are assumed under higher tree canopy cover.

Representation

Data show the percentage of the land surface under tree canopy cover.

Source

)2001 National Land Cover Dataset (NLCD).
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: National Land Cover Dataset.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation type
page.title: Vegetation type
page.description:
Different vegetation types will promote or reduce infiltration of water.

Role in models

Vegetation type is used as an input to the probabilistic model of the "green infrastructure" component of flood regulation. Certain land cover types, such as wetlands, forests, and grasslands are likely to have greater capacity for flood regulation than developed or cultivated land cover types.

Representation

Data are categorical, derived from NLCD land cover classes.

Source

National Land Cover Dataset (NLCD).
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: National Land Cover Dataset.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation type
page.title: Vegetation type
page.description:
Different vegetation types will promote or reduce infiltration of water.

Role in models

Vegetation type is used as an input to the probabilistic model of the "green infrastructure" component of flood regulation. Certain land cover types, such as wetlands, forests, and grasslands are likely to have greater capacity for flood regulation than developed or cultivated land cover types.

Representation

Data are categorical, derived from NLCD land cover classes.

Source

National Land Cover Dataset (NLCD).
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: National Land Cover Dataset.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Soil infiltration
page.title: Soil infiltration
page.description:
Surface water absorbed by the soil, potentially becoming available as groundwater.

Role in models

This is an intermediate node in the Bayesian network that accounts for soil infiltration in reducing the quantity of floodwater.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of water infiltrated per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution of the amount of water infiltrated. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Evapotranspiration
page.title: Evapotranspiration
page.description:
Surface water evaporated or taken up by vegetation and transpired, becoming no longer available as surface or groundwater.

Role in models

This is an intermediate node in the Bayesian network that accounts for the contribution of vegetation in reducing the quantity of floodwater. While evapotranspiration does not operate on the same timescale as flooding, for our initial models of flood mitigaiton, which take place using annual precipitation data, evapotranspiration is used as a proxy for the effects of vegetation in mitigating floodwater.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of water evaporated or transpired per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution of the amount of water infiltrated. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Green infrastructure storage
page.title: Green infrastructure storage
page.description:
Total floodwater absorption and detention capacity in soils, vegetation, and floodplains.

Role in models

This is the output of a probabilistic model accounting for the influence of soil, vegetation, and their saturation on floodwater absorption and detention capacity. Results are summed with "gray infrastructure" storage to give total flood regulation values, and then passed to the flow model to estimate actual flood mitigation given the location of sources of floodwater and beneficiaries at risk of flooding.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of floodwater absorbed or detained per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution of the amount of floodwater regulated. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Dam storage
page.title: Dam storage
page.description:
The storage capacity of floodwater by dams.

Role in models

Dam storage can be summed with detention basin storage to give total "gray infrastructure" storage, which is then summed with "green infrastructure" storage to estimate total natural and artificial flood regulation capacity.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of floodwater detention capacity by each reservoir.

Source

National Atlas of the United States, Major Dams of the United States.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Major dams of the United States.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Detention basin storage
page.title: Detention basin storage
page.description:
Storage of flood waters in detention basins.

Role in models

Detention basin storage can be summed with storage behind dams to give total "gray infrastructure" storage, which is then summed with "green infrastructure" storage to estimate total natural and artificial flood regulation capacity.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of detention basins.

Source

County stormwater managment data (where available).
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Gray infrastructure storage
page.title: Gray infrastructure storage
page.description:
The sum of floodwater storage by dams, detention basins, or other engineered infrastructure.

Role in models

Results are summed with "green infrastructure" storage to give total flood regulation values, and then passed to the flow model to estimate actual flood mitigation given the location of sources of floodwater and lives and property at risk of flooding.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of floodwater absorbed or detained per year.

Source

Calculated deterministically as the sum of dam and detention basin storage.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Annual flood sink
page.title: Annual flood sink
page.description:
The sum of "green" and "gray" infrastructure, e.g., all rainwater and floodwater detained and infiltrated by natural features and engineered infrastructure.

Role in models

This is the total potential flood regulation by both natural and artificial flood control features, currently estimated using annual precipitation data. These data are passed to the flood flow model, which calculates actual flood risk, given precipitation levels and the location of lives and property at risk of flooding.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of floodwater absorbed or detained per year.

Source

Calculated as the sum of outputs from a probabilistic model of "green infrastructure" storage plus storage capacity of artificial detention basins and dams.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: 100-year floodplain extent
page.title: 100-year floodplain
page.description:
The extent of the mapped 100-year floodplain.

Role in models

Floodplain extents are inputs to the use models to identify the presence of lives and property located in the flood zone. These are the beneficiaries of flood regulation, who are at risk of flooding in the absence of natural or engineered flood control measures. Floodplain extents are also used in the flood flow models to distribute floodwater across the floodplain.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence map of the 100-year floodplain.

Source

FEMA Q3 Flood Data.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: FEMA Q3 Flood Data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Farmland
page.title: Farmland
page.description:
Farmland at risk of flood damage to crops.

Role in models

Farmland locations are intersected with floodplain extents data to map the potential beneficiaries of flood regulation. The flood flow model is then used to estimate actual flood regulation values.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of farmland.

Source

National Land Cover Dataset (NLCD).
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: National Land Cover Dataset.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Farmland in 100-year floodplain
page.title: Farmland in 100-year floodplain
page.description:
Protection of farmland located in the 100-year floodplain by ecosystems and engineered flood control infrastructure helps avoid crop damage and loss during flood events.

Role in models

This is one beneficiary group for flood regulation. The location of farmland at risk of flooding is passed to the flow model, which calculates actual flood risk, given precipitation levels and the location of sinks that reduce flood flows.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of farmland in the 100-year floodplain.

Source

Intersection of FEMA 100-year floodplain data and NLCD farmland cover data.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Rivers
page.title: Rivers
page.description:
River and stream locations.

Role in models

Hydrography data are used to route floodwater across the land surface. The flow model moves precipitation downslope using elevation data until it reaches a stream network, which floodwater then follows, spreading across the floodplain as it moves downstream.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of rivers and streams.

Source

Cal-Atlas Geospatial Clearinghouse; Washington Department of Natural Resources.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Washington State DNR, Cal-Atlas Geospatial Clearinghouse.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Elevation
page.title: Elevation
page.description:
Elevation above sea level.

Role in models

A digital elevation model is used along with hydrography data to route floodwater across the land surface. The flow model moves precipitation downslope using elevation data until it reaches a stream network, which floodwater then follows, spreading across the floodplain as it moves downstream.

Representation

Data are in physical units of meters above sea level.

Source

Global 90-m SRTM digital elevation model.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Shuttle Radar Topography Mission data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Levees
page.title: Levees
page.description:
Levees restrict floodwater to the river channel, protecting lives and property immediately behind the levee as long as it is not breached, but speeding the flow of floodwater downstream.

Role in models

Levee location data are used in the flow model to limit the spread of floodwater across the floodplain when levees are present.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of levees.

Source

County GIS offices (where available).
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Potential damage
page.title: Potentially damaging flood flow
page.description:
*Possible flow maps* show the path that the carrier of the service would take if it was not intercepted by sinks. As such it considers source and use models and shows the maximum amount of flow.
For provisioning services, this corresponds to the maximum potential benefit; for preventive services, the maximum potential damage.
This map shows the flow route of floodwater across the landscape in the absence of sinks. Therefore it computes the maximum damage that would happen if natural features did not intercept it, and provides a baseline that allows estimation of the actual value of those features.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Potentially damaging runoff
page.title: Source of potentially damaging runoff
page.description:
*Possible source maps*, generated through flow analysis, show which specific sources actually generate carriers that reach users, independent of the existence of sinks but taking into account use values and the carrier flow paths. Even in the absence of sinks, not all of a source quantity can actually reach users, because of the route that an ecosystem service carrier moves across the landscape.
For provisioning services, this corresponds to the source of benefits that has the potential of being actually useful. For preventive services, this corresponds to the sources that could actually cause damage to people. The location and strength of sinks determines how much of the source actually reaches the users.
This map shows runoff capable of harming people or damaging property when accounting for flow paths but not sinks.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Potential damage
page.title: Potential flood damage
page.description:
*Possible use maps* show the locations of users that can receive a benefit due to flow connections with a source of an ecosystem service carrier, but may or may not actually receive the carrier due to the action of sinks.
For provisioning services, potential use identifies areas where it is physically possible for a benefit to be received. For preventive services, potential use identifies areas that may be damaged by a detrimental carrier if sinks do not prevent such damage.
This map shows people and property receiving damage when accounting for sources of floodwater and its flow path but not accounting for the action of sinks that reduce potential damage from floodwater - in other words, the damage that would occur in the absence of flood-mitigating sinks.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Actual flood
page.title: Actual flood flow
page.description:
*Actual flow maps* show the flow paths that deliver actual services to beneficiaries. These are selected from the total flow density to only show these flow paths that are not depleted by sinks and actually reach users.
For provisioning services, these flow paths deliver valuable benefits to the users and the density is proportional to the value accrued. For preventive services, the flow paths show how much of the carrier reaches users, delivering actual damage.
In this case, the density of actual flows shows floodwater that impacts people or property, after accounting for flood routing due to topography, stream networks, and natural and artificial features that detain, slow, or infiltrate floodwater.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Flood source
page.title: Flood damaging runoff
page.description:
*Actual source maps* show sources that actually provide a service after accounting for sinks and flow dynamics.
For provisioning services, this is the amount and location of a benefit that actually provides benefits to the users. For preventive services, it shows where the actual damage came from. Source regions that provided a damaging carrier that was neutralized by sinks are not shown.
This map shows runoff that actually harms people or property when accounting for flow paths and sinks.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Actual mitigation
page.title: Utilized runoff mitigation
page.description:
*Actual sink maps* shows the sinks that actually contribute to depleting a service carrier given its flow patterns.
For provisioning services, such sinks reduce benefits to users compared to their possible value. For preventive services, such sinks provide the actual service because they prevent a damaging carrier from reaching users.
This map shows sinks that actively reduce floodwater, providing the benefit of reduced flood damage.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Actual damage
page.title: Flood damage received
page.description:
*Actual use maps* show the level of use of a beneficial carrier for a provisioning service or damage caused by a detrimental carrier for a preventive service, for users.
This map shows actual damage received by people and property when accounting for sources of floodwater and their sinks and flow paths.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Absorbed floodwater
page.title: Absorbed flood flow
page.description:
*Blocked flow maps* show flow paths that could have delivered an ecosystem service to humans based on the flow routes and source and user locations, but did not because of the action of sinks. These are selected from among all actual flows.
For provisioning services, these flow paths show the loss of possible beneficial service flow to users, and their density is proportional to the value lost. For preventive services, the flow paths show the amount of the total flow that was prevented by natural features from causing damage.
This map shows flood flows that are absorbed by sinks prior to reaching people or property at risk of flooding.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Mitigated floodwater
page.title: Mitigated flood source
page.description:
*Blocked source maps* show sources that had the possibility of reaching users given the location of users and flow dynamics, but were blocked from doing so because of the action of sinks.
For provisioning services, this corresponds to value produced by the environment but lost before it could reach the users. For preventive services, it corresponds to damage that could have been inflicted on users but was blocked by natural features.
This map shows the portion of the total runoff that is absorbed, detained, or slowed by the action of flood sinks.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Total benefit
page.title: Flood mitigation benefits accrued
page.description:
*Blocked use maps* show users that would have received a service carrier based on source and flow dynamics, but did not because of the action of sinks.
For provisioning services, the map shows possible value that were prevented by sinks from reaching users; for preventive services, it shows actual value accrued by users from sinks that blocked damaging flows. For preventive services, therefore, this map is the ultimate quantification of value given the locations and quantity of users and sink features.
This map shows people or economically valuable assets who are spared from flood damage due to the flood regulation provided by sinks.
page.see-also: Flood regulation model details from the ARIES website
